cRefPattern.p: This pointer pattern extracts act, scene, and line.
This pointer pattern extracts act and scene.

castGroup.head: lords attending on the Princess of France.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: Enter FERDINAND, king of NAVARRE, BIRON, LONGAVILLE, and DUMAIN.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let fame, that all hunt after in their lives,
Live register'd upon our brazen tombs
And then grace us in the disgrace of death;
When, spite of cormorant devouring Time,
The endeavour of this present breath may buy
That honour which shall bate his scythe's keen edge
And make us heirs of all eternity.
Therefore, brave conquerors,--for so you are,
That war against your own affections
And the huge army of the world's desires,--
Our late edict shall strongly stand in force:
Navarre shall be the wonder of the world;
Our court shall be a little Academe,
Still and contemplative in living art.
You three, Biron, Dumain, and Longaville,
Have sworn for three years' term to live with me
My fellow-scholars and to keep those statutes
That are recorded in this schedule here:
Your oaths are pass'd; and now subscribe your names,
That his own hand may strike his honour down
That violates the smallest branch herein:
If you are arm'd to do as sworn to do,
Subscribe to your deep oaths, and keep it too.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I am resolved; 'tis but a three years' fast:
The mind shall banquet, though the body pine:
Fat paunches have lean pates, and dainty bits
Make rich the ribs, but bankrupt quite the wits.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: My loving lord, Dumain is mortified:
The grosser manner of these world's delights
He throws upon the gross world's baser slaves:
To love, to wealth, to pomp, I pine and die;
With all these living in philosophy.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: I can but say their protestation over;
So much, dear liege, I have already sworn,
That is, to live and study here three years.
But there are other strict observances;
As, not to see a woman in that term,
Which I hope well is not enrolled there;
And one day in a week to touch no food
And but one meal on every day beside,
The which I hope is not enrolled there;
And then, to sleep but three hours in the night,
And not be seen to wink of all the day--
When I was wont to think no harm all night
And make a dark night too of half the day--
Which I hope well is not enrolled there:
O, these are barren tasks, too hard to keep,
Not to see ladies, study, fast, not sleep!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your oath is pass'd to pass away from these.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Let me say no, my liege, an if you please:
I only swore to study with your grace
And stay here in your court for three years' space.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You swore to that, Biron, and to the rest.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: By yea and nay, sir, then I swore in jest.
What is the end of study? let me know.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l:
Why, that to know, which else we should not
know.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Things hid and barr'd, you mean, from common sense?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay, that is study's god-like recompense.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Come on, then; I will swear to study so,
To know the thing I am forbid to know:
As thus,--to study where I well may dine,
When I to feast expressly am forbid;
Or study where to meet some mistress fine,
When mistresses from common sense are hid;
Or, having sworn too hard a keeping oath,
Study to break it and not break my troth.
If study's gain be thus and this be so,
Study knows that which yet it doth not know:
Swear me to this, and I will ne'er say no.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: These be the stops that hinder study quite
And train our intellects to vain delight.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Why, all delights are vain; but that most vain,
Which with pain purchased doth inherit pain:
As, painfully to pore upon a book
To seek the light of truth; while truth the while
Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look:
Light seeking light doth light of light beguile:
So, ere you find where light in darkness lies,
Your light grows dark by losing of your eyes.
Study me how to please the eye indeed
By fixing it upon a fairer eye,
Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed
And give him light that it was blinded by.
Study is like the heaven's glorious sun
That will not be deep-search'd with saucy looks:
Small have continual plodders ever won
Save base authority from others' books.
These earthly godfathers of heaven's lights
That give a name to every fixed star
Have no more profit of their shining nights
Than those that walk and wot not what they are.
Too much to know is to know nought but fame;
And every godfather can give a name.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How well he's read, to reason against reading!

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Proceeded well, to stop all good proceeding!

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l:
He weeds the corn and still lets grow the
weeding.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l:
The spring is near when green geese are
a-breeding.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: How follows that?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Fit in his place and time.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: In reason nothing.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Something then in rhyme.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Biron is like an envious sneaping frost,
That bites the first-born infants of the spring.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Well, say I am; why should proud summer boast
Before the birds have any cause to sing?
Why should I joy in any abortive birth?
At Christmas I no more desire a rose
Than wish a snow in May's new-fangled mirth;
But like of each thing that in season grows.
So you, to study now it is too late,
Climb o'er the house to unlock the little gate.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well, sit you out: go home, Biron: adieu.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: No, my good lord; I have sworn to stay with you:
And though I have for barbarism spoke more
Than for that angel knowledge you can say,
Yet confident I'll keep what I have swore
And bide the penance of each three years' day.
Give me the paper; let me read the same;
And to the strict'st decrees I'll write my name.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How well this yielding rescues thee from shame!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
'Item, That no woman
shall come within a mile
of my court:'
Hath
this been proclaimed?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Four days ago.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
Let's see the penalty. Reads
'On
pain of losing her tongue.'
Who devised this
penalty?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Marry, that did I.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: Sweet lord, and why?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: To fright them hence with that dread penalty.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
A dangerous law against gentility!
Reads'Item, If any man be seen to talk
with a woman within
the term of three years,
he shall endure such
public shame as the rest
of the court can possibly
devise.'
sp.l: This article, my liege, yourself must break;
For well you know here comes in embassy
The French king's daughter with yourself to speak--
A maid of grace and complete majesty--
About surrender up of Aquitaine
To her decrepit, sick and bedrid father:
Therefore this article is made in vain,
Or vainly comes the admired princess hither.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l:
What say you, lords?
why, this was quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: So study evermore is overshot:
While it doth study to have what it would
It doth forget to do the thing it should,
And when it hath the thing it hunteth most,
'Tis won as towns with fire, so won, so lost.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We must of force dispense with this decree;
She must lie here on mere necessity.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Necessity will make us forsworn
Three thousand times within this three years' space;
For every man with his affects is born,
Not by might mastered but by special grace:
If I break faith, this word shall speak for me;
I am forsworn on 'mere necessity.'
So to the laws at large I write my name:Subscribes.
And he that breaks them in the least degree
Stands in attainder of eternal shame:
Suggestions are to other as to me;
But I believe, although I seem so loath,
I am the last that will last keep his oath.
But is there no quick recreation granted?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay, that there is. Our court, you know, is haunted
With a refined traveller of Spain;
A man in all the world's new fashion planted,
That hath a mint of phrases in his brain;
One whom the music of his own vain tongue
Doth ravish like enchanting harmony;
A man of complements, whom right and wrong
Have chose as umpire of their mutiny:
This child of fancy, that Armado hight,
For interim to our studies shall relate
In high-born words the worth of many a knight
From tawny Spain lost in the world's debate.
How you delight, my lords, I know not, I;
But, I protest, I love to hear him lie
And I will use him for my minstrelsy.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Armado is a most illustrious wight,
A man of fire-new words, fashion's own knight.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Costard the swain and he shall be our sport;

And so to study, three years is but short.
Enter DULL with a letter, and COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Which is the duke's own person?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: This, fellow: what wouldst?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
I myself reprehend his own person,
for I am
his grace's tharborough; but I would
see his own person
in flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: This is he.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
Signior Arme--Arme--commends
you.
There's villany abroad: this letter will
tell you more.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Sir, the contempts thereof are as
touching
me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
How low soever the matter, I hope
in God for
high words.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
A high hope for a low heaven: God
grant us
patience!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: To hear? or forbear laughing?

sp.speaker: Long.
Biron.
sp.p:
Well, sir, be it as the style shall
give us cause to
climb in the merriness.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
The matter is to me, sir, as concerning
Jaquenetta.
The manner of it is, I was
taken with the manner.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: In what manner?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
In manner and form following, sir;
all those three:
I was seen with her in the
manor-house, sitting with
her upon the form,
and taken following her into the
park; which,
put together, is in manner and form
following.
Now, sir, for the manner,--it is the manner
of
a man to speak to a woman: for the form,--
in some
form.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: For the following, sir?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
As it shall follow in my correction:
and God defend
the right!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Will you hear this letter with attention?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: As we would hear an oracle.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Such is the simplicity of man to
hearken after the
flesh.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'Great deputy, the welkin's
vicegerent and sole dominator
of Navarre, my
soul's earth's god, and body's fostering
patron.'

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Not a word of Costard yet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'So it is,'--

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
It may be so: but if he say it is so,
he is, in telling
true, but so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Peace!

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Be to me and every man that dares
not fight!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No words!

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Of other men's secrets, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'So it is, besieged with
sable-coloured melancholy, I
did commend the
black-oppressing humour to the most wholesome
physic of thy health-giving air; and, as
I am a gentleman,
betook myself to walk. The
time when. About the
sixth hour; when
beasts most graze, birds best peck, and men
sit
down to that nourishment which is called
supper: so much
for the time when. Now for
the ground which; which, I
mean, I walked
upon: it is ycleped thy park. Then for the
place where; where, I mean, I did encounter
that obscene and
preposterous event, that
draweth from my snow-white pen
the ebon-colored
ink, which here thou viewest, beholdest,
surveyest, or seest; but to the place
where; it standeth
north-north-east and by
east from the west corner of thy
curious-knotted
garden: there did I see that low-spirited
swain, that base minnow of thy mirth,'--

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'that unlettered small-know-
ing soul,'--

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'that shallow
vassal,'--

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Still me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'which, as I remember,
hight Costard,--

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: O, me!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'sorted and consorted, contrary
to thy established
proclaimed edict and
continent canon, which
with,--O, with--but
with this I passion to say wherewith,--

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: With a wench.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'with a child of our grandmother
Eve, a female;
or, for thy more sweet
understanding, a woman. Him I, as my
ever-esteemed
duty pricks me on, have sent to thee,
to receive
the meed of punishment, by thy
sweet grace's officer, Anthony
Dull; a man of
good repute, carriage, bearing, and estimation.'

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
Me, an't shall please you; I am Anthony
Dull.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'For Jaquenetta,--so is the
weaker vessel called
which I apprehended
with the aforesaid swain,--I keep her
as a
vessel of the law's fury; and shall, at the
least of thy
sweet notice, bring her to trial.
Thine, in all compliments of
devoted and
heart-burning heat of duty.
DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.'

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
This is not so well as I looked for,
but the best
that ever I heard.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Ay, the best for the worst. But, sirrah,
what say you
to this?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Sir, I confess the wench.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Did you hear the proclamation?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
I do confess much of the hearing it
but little
of the marking of it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
It was proclaimed a year's imprisonment,
to be
taken with a wench.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
I was taken with none, sir: I was
taken with a
damsel.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well, it was proclaimed 'damsel.'

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
This was no damsel, neither, sir; she
was a
virgin.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
It is so varied, too; for it was proclaimed
'virgin.'

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
If it were, I deny her virginity: I
was taken
with a maid.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
This maid will not serve your turn,
sir.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: This maid will serve my turn, sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Sir, I will pronounce your sentence:
you shall
fast a week with bran and water.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
I had rather pray a month with
mutton and
porridge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And Don Armado shall be your keeper.
My lord Biron, see him deliver'd o'er:
And go we, lords, to put in practice that
Which each to other hath so strongly sworn.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: I'll lay my head to any good man's hat,
These oaths and laws will prove an idle scorn.
Sirrah, come on.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
I suffer for the truth, sir; for true it
is,I was taken
with Jaquenetta, and Jaquenetta
is a true girl; and
therefore welcome the
sour cup of prosperity! Affliction
may one
day smile again; and till then, sit thee down,
sorrow! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Boy, what sign is it when a man of
great
spirit grows melancholy?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
A great sign, sir, that he will look
sad.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Why, sadness is one and the self-same
thing,
dear imp.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: No, no; O Lord, sir, no.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
How canst thou part sadness and
melancholy,
my tender juvenal?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
By a familiar demonstration of the
working, my
tough senior.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Why tough senior? why tough senior?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Why tender juvenal? why tender
juvenal?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I spoke it, tender juvenal, as a congruent
epitheton
appertaining to thy young
days, which we may
nominate tender.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
And I, tough senior, as an appertinent
title to
your old time, which we may
name tough.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Pretty and apt.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
How mean you, sir? I pretty, and
my saying apt?
or I apt, and my saying
pretty?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Thou pretty, because little.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Little pretty, because little. Wherefore
apt?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: And therefore apt, because quick.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Speak you this in my praise, master?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: In thy condign praise.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
I will praise an eel with the same
praise.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: What, that an eel is ingenious?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: That an eel is quick.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I do say thou art quick in answers:
thou
heatest my blood.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I am answered, sir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I love not to be crossed.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
He speaks the mere contrary;
crosses love not him.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I have promised to study three years
with the duke.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: You may do it in an hour, sir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: How many is one thrice told?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I am ill at reckoning; it fitteth the
spirit of a tapster.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
You are a gentleman and a gamester,sir.
ed=G>

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I confess both: they are both the
varnish of a
complete man.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Then, I am sure, you know how
much the gross
sum of deuce-ace amounts to.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: It doth amount to one more than two.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Which the base vulgar do call three.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Why, sir, is this such a piece of
study?
Now here is three studied, ere ye'll
thrice wink: and how
easy it is to put' years'
to the word 'three,' and study three
years in
two words, the dancing horse will tell you.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: A most fine figure!

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: To prove you a cipher.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I will hereupon confess I am in love:
and as
it is base for a soldier to love, so am I
in love with a
base wench. If drawing my
sword against the humour
of affection would
deliver me from the reprobate
thought of it, I
would take Desire prisoner, and ransom
him
to any French courtier for a new-devised
courtesy. I
think scorn to sigh: methinks I
should outswear
Cupid. Comfort, me, boy:
what great men have been
in love?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Hercules, master.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Most sweet Hercules! More authority,dear 

boy, name more;
       and, sweet my 
child, let them be men 
of good repute and
       carriage.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Samson, master: he was a man of
good carriage,
great carriage, for he carried
the town-gates on his
back like a porter: and
he was in love.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
O well-knit Samson! strong-jointed
Samson!
I do excel thee in my rapier as much
as thou didst me
in carrying gates. I am in
love, too. Who was Samson's
love, my dear
Moth?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: A woman, master.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Of what complexion?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Of all the four, or the three, or the
two, or one
of the four.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Of the sea-water green, sir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Is that one of the four complexions?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
As I have read, sir; and the best of
them too.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Green indeed is the colour of lovers;
but to
have a love of that colour, methinks
Samson had small
reason for it. He surely
affected her for her wit.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
It was so, sir; for she had a green
wit.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
My love is most immaculate white
and red.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Most maculate thoughts, master,
are masked
under such colours.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Define, define, well-educated infant.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
My father's wit and my mother's
tongue, assist
me!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Sweet invocation of a child; most
pretty and
pathetical!

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: If she be made of white and red,
Her faults will ne'er be known,
For blushing cheeks by faults are bred
And fears by pale white shown:
Then if she fear, or be to blame,
By this you shall not know,
For still her cheeks possess the same
Which native she doth owe.
sp.p:
A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason
of white
and red.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Is there not a ballad, boy, of the
King and the
Beggar?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
The world was very guilty of such a
ballad some
three ages since: but I think now
'tis not to be found; or,
if it were, it would
neither serve for the writing nor the
tune.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I will have that subject newly writ
o'er, that I
may example my digression by
some mighty precedent.
Boy, I do love that
country girl that I took in
the park with the
rational hind Costard: she deserves
well.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
To be whipped; and yet a
better love than my
master.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Sing, boy; my spirit grows heavy in
love.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
And that's great marvel, loving a
light wench.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I say, sing.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Forbear till this company be past.
Enter DULL, COSTARD, and JAQUENETTA.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
Sir, the duke's pleasure is, that you
keep Costard
safe: and you must suffer him
to take no delight nor no
penance; but a' must
fast three days a week. For this
damsel, I
must keep her at the park: she is allowed for
the day-woman. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I do betray myself with blushing.
Maid!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Man?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I will visit thee at the lodge.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: That's hereby.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I know where it is situate.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Lord, how wise you are!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I will tell thee wonders.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: With that face?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I love thee.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: So I heard you say.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: And so, farewell.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Fair weather after you!

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Come, Jaquenetta, away! Exeunt Dull and Jaquenetta.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offences
ere
thou be pardoned.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Well, sir, I hope, when I do it, I
shall do it on a
full stomach.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
I am more bound to you than your
fellows, for
they are but lightly rewarded.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Take away this villain; shut him up.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Come, you transgressing slave; away!

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Let me not be pent up, sir: I will
fast, being
loose.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
No, sir; that were fast and loose:
thou shalt to
prison.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Well, if ever I do see the merry days
of desolation
that I have seen, some shall see.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: What shall some see?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Nay, nothing, Master Moth, but
what they
look upon. It is not for prisoners to
be too silent in their
words; and therefore I
will say nothing: I thank God I
have as little
patience as another man; and therefore I
can
be quiet. Exeunt Moth and Costard.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I do affect the very ground, which is
base,
where her shoe, which is baser, guided
by her foot,
which is basest, doth tread. I shall
be forsworn, which
is a great argument of
falsehood, if I love. And how can
that be
true love which is falsely attempted? Love is
a familiar;
Love is a devil: there is no evil
angel but
Love. Yet was Samson so tempted,
and he had an excellent
strength; yet was
Solomon so seduced, and he had
a very good
wit. Cupid's butt-shaft is too hard for Hercules'
club; and therefore too much odds for a
Spaniard's
rapier. The first and second cause
will not serve
my turn; the passado he respects
not, the duello he
regards not: his disgrace
is to be called boy; but his
glory is to
subdue men. Adieu, valour! rust, rapier! be
still, drum! for your manager is in love; yea,
he loveth.
Assist me, some extemporal god
of rhyme, for I am sure I
shall turn sonnet.
Devise, wit; write, pen; for I am for
whole
volumes in folio. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: Enter the Princess of France, ROSALINE, MARIA, KATHARINE, BOYET, Lords, and other Attendants.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Now, madam, summon up your dearest spirits:
Consider who the king your father sends,
To whom he sends, and what's his embassy:
Yourself, held precious in the world's esteem,
To parley with the sole inheritor
Of all perfections that a man may owe,
Matchless Navarre; the plea of no less weight
Than Aquitaine, a dowry for a queen.
Be now as prodigal of all dear grace
As Nature was in making graces dear
When she did starve the general world beside
And prodigally gave them all to you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good Lord Boyet, my beauty, though but mean,
Needs not the painted flourish of your praise:
Beauty is bought by judgement of the eye,
Not utter'd by base sale of chapmen's tongues:
I am less proud to hear you tell my worth
Than you much willing to be counted wise
In spending your wit in the praise of mine.
But now to task the tasker: good Boyet,
You are not ignorant, all-telling fame
Doth noise abroad, Navarre hath made a vow,
Till painful study shall outwear three years,
No woman may approach his silent court:
Therefore to's seemeth it a needful course,
Before we enter his forbidden gates,
To know his pleasure; and in that behalf,
Bold of your worthiness, we single you
As our best-moving fair solicitor.
Tell him, the daughter of the King of France,
On serious business, craving quick dispatch,
Importunes personal conference with his grace:
Haste, signify so much; while we attend,
Like humble-visaged suitors, his high will.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Proud of employment, willingly I go.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: All pride is willing pride, and yours is so. Exit Boyet.
Who are the votaries, my loving lords,
That are vow-fellows with this virtuous duke?

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l: Lord Longaville is one.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Know you the man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know him, madam: at a marriagefeast,
Between Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir
Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnized
In Normandy, saw I this Longaville:
A man of sovereign parts he is esteem'd;
Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms:
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
The only soil of his fair virtue's gloss,
If virtue's gloss will stain with any soil,
Is a sharp wit match'd with too blunt a will;
Whose edge hath power to cut, whose will still wills
It should none spare that come within his power.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Some merry mocking lord, belike; is 't so?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They say so most that most his humours know.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Such short-lived wits do wither as they grow.
Who are the rest?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: The young Dumain; a well-accomplished youth,
Of all that virtue love for virtue loved:
Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill;
For he hath wit to make an ill shape good,
And shape to win grace though he had no wit.
I saw him at the Duke Alencon's once;
And much too little of that good I saw
Is my report to his great worthiness.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Another of these students at that time
Was there with him, if I have heard a truth.
Biron they call him; but a merrier man,
Within the limit of becoming mirth,
I never spent an hour's talk withal:
His eye begets occasion for his wit;
For every object that the one doth catch
The other turns to a mirth-moving jest,
Which his fair tongue, conceit's expositor,
Delivers in such apt and gracious words
That aged ears play truant at his tales
And younger hearings are quite ravished;
So sweet and voluble is his discourse.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: God bless my ladies! are they all in love,
That every one her own hath garnished
With such bedecking ornaments of praise?

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l:
Here comes Boyet.
Re-enter BOYET.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Now, what admittance, lord?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Navarre had notice of your fair approach;
And he and his competitors in oath
Were all address'd to meet you, gentle lady,
Before I came. Marry, thus much I have learnt:
He rather means to lodge you in the field,
Like one that comes here to besiege his court,
Than seek a dispensation for his oath,
To let you enter his unpeopled house.
Here comes Navarre. Enter KING, LONGAVILLE, DUMAIN, BIRON, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fair princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
'Fair' I give you back again; and
'welcome' I
have not yet: the roof of this
court is too high to be
yours; and welcome
to the wide fields too base to be
mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I will be welcome, then: conduct me thither.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hear me, dear lady; I have sworn an oath.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Our Lady help my lord! he'll be forsworn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Why, will shall break it; will and nothing else.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your ladyship is ignorant what it is.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise,
Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance.
I hear your grace hath sworn out house-keeping:
'Tis deadly sin to keep that oath, my lord,
And sin to break it.
But pardon me, I am too sudden-bold:
To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming,
And suddenly resolve me in my suit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Madam, I will, if suddenly I may.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You will the sooner, that I were away;
For you'll prove perjured if you make me stay.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: I know you did.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: How needless was it then to ask the question!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: You must not be so quick.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: 'Tis 'long of you that spur me with such questions.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Your wit's too hot, it speeds too fast, 'twill tire.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: What time o' day?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: The hour that fools should ask.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: Now fair befall your mask!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Fair fall the face it covers!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: And send you many lovers!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Amen, so you be none.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: Nay, then will I be gone.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Madam, your father here doth intimate
The payment of a hundred thousand crowns;
Being but the one half of an entire sum
Disbursed by my father in his wars.
But say that he or we, as neither have,
Received that sum, yet there remains unpaid
A hundred thousand more; in surety of the which,
One part of Aquitaine is bound to us,
Although not valued to the money's worth.
If then the king your father will restore
But that one half which is unsatisfied,
We will give up our right in Aquitaine,
And hold fair friendship with his majesty.
But that, it seems, he little purposeth,
For here he doth demand to have repaid
A hundred thousand crowns; and not demands,
On payment of a hundred thousand crowns,
To have his title live in Aquitaine;
Which we much rather had depart withal
And have the money by our father lent
Than Aquitaine so gelded as it is.
Dear princess, were not his requests so far
From reason's yielding, your fair self should make
A yielding 'gainst some reason in my breast
And go well satisfied to France again.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You do the king my father too much wrong
And wrong the reputation of your name,
In so unseeming to confess receipt
Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do protest I never heard of it;
And if you prove it, I'll repay it back
Or yield up Aquitaine.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: We arrest your word.
Boyet, you can produce acquittances
For such a sum from special officers
Of Charles his father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Satisfy me so.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: So please your grace, the packet is not come
Where that and other specialties are bound:
To-morrow you shall have a sight of them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It shall suffice me: at which interview
All liberal reason I will yield unto.
Meantime receive such welcome at my hand
As honour without breach of honour may
Make tender of to thy true worthiness:
You may not come, fair princess, in my gates;
But here without you shall be so received
As you shall deem yourself lodged in my heart,
Though so denied fair harbour in my house.
Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell:
To-morrow shall we visit you again.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Sweet health and fair desires consort your grace!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy own wish wish I thee in every place! Exit.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Lady, I will commend you to mine own heart.

sp.speaker: Ros.
Biron.
sp.p: I would you heard it groan.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Is the fool sick?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: Sick at the heart.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Alack, let it blood.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: Would that do it good?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My physic says 'ay.'

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: Will you prick't with your eye?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: No point, with my knife.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Now, God save thy life!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And yours from long living!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: I cannot stay thanksgiving. Retiring.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Sir, I pray you, a word: what lady is that same?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: The heir of Alencon, Katharine her name.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: A gallant lady. Monsieur, fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I beseech you a word: what is she in the white?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: A woman sometimes, an you saw her in the light.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Perchance light in the light. I desire her name.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l:
She hath but one for herself;
to desire that were a shame.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Pray you, sir, whose daughter?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: Her mother's, I have heard.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: God's blessing on your beard!

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p:
Good sir, be not offended.
She is an heir of Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Nay, my choler is ended.
She is a most sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: Not unlike, sir, that may be. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: What's her name in the cap?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: Rosaline, by good hap.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: Is she wedded or no?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: To her will, sir, or so.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: You are welcome, sir: adieu.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Farewell to me, sir, and welcome to you. Exit Biron.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That last is Biron, the merry madcap lord:
Not a word with him but a jest.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: And every jest but a word.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Two hot sheeps, marry.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: And wherefore not ships?
No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You sheep, and I pasture: shall that finish the jest?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: So you grant pasture for me. Offering to kiss her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not so, gentle beast:
My lips are no common, though several they be.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Belonging to whom?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To my fortunes and me.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good wits will be jangling; but, gentles, agree:
This civil war of wits were much better used
On Navarre and his book-men; for here 'tis abused.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: If my observation, which very seldom lies,
By the heart's still rhetoric disclosed with eyes,
Deceive me not now, Navarre is infected.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: With that which we lovers entitle affected.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Why, all his behaviours did make their retire
To the court of his eye, peeping through desire:
His heart, like an agate, with your print impress'd,
Proud with his form, in his eye pride express'd:
His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see,
Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be;
All senses to that sense did make their repair,
To feel only looking on fairest of fair:
Methought all his senses were lock'd in his eye,
As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy;
Who, tendering their own worth from where they were glass'd,
Did point you to buy them, along as you pass'd:
His face's own margent did quote such amazes
That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.
I'll give you Aquitaine and all that is his,
An you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Come to our pavilion: Boyet is disposed.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: But to speak that in words which his eye hath disclosed.
I only have made a mouth of his eye,
By adding a tongue which I know will not lie.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l:
Thou art an old love-monger and speakest
skilfully.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l:
He is Cupid's grandfather and learns news
of him.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l:
Then was Venus like her mother, for her father
is but grim.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Do you hear, my mad wenches?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: What then, do you see?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Ay, our way to be gone.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: You are too hard for me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Warble, child; make passionate my
sense of
hearing.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Concolinel. Singing.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years;
take
this key, give enlargement to the swain,
bring him festinately
hither: I must employ
him in a letter to my
love.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: How meanest thou? brawling in French?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
No, my complete master: but to jig
off a tune
at the tongue's end, canary to it
with your feet. humor
it with turning up your
eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note,
sometime
through the throat, as if you swallowed love
with singing love, sometime through the nose,
as if you
snuffed up love by smelling love;
with your hat penthouse-like
o'er the shop of
your eyes; with your arms crossed on
your
thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or
your
hands in your pocket like a man after
the old painting;
and keep not too long in one
tune, but a snip and away.
These are complements,
these are humours; these betray
nice
wenches, that would be betrayed without
these; and
make them men of note--do you
note me?--that most are
affected to these.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: How hast thou purchased this experience?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: By my penny of observation.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: But O,--but O,--

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: 'The hobby-horse is forgot.'

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Callest thou my love 'hobby-horse'?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
No, master; the hobby-horse is but
a colt,
and your love perhaps a hackney.
But
have you forgot your love?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Almost I had.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Negligent student! learn her by
heart.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: By heart and in heart, boy.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
And out of heart, master: all those
three I will
prove.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: What wilt thou prove?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
A man, if I live; and this, by, in,
and without, upon
the instant: by heart you
love her, because your heart
cannot come by
her; in heart you love her, because your
heart
is in love with her; and out of heart you love
her,
being out of heart that you cannot enjoy
her.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I am all these three.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
And three times as much more, and
yet nothing
at all.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l:
Fetch hither the swain: he must carry me a
letter.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
A message well sympathized; a
horse to be ambassador
for an ass.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Ha, ha! what sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, you must send the ass
upon the horse,
for he is very slow-gaited. But
I go.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: The way is but short: away!

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: As swift as lead, sir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
The meaning, pretty ingenious?
Is not lead a
metal heavy, dull, and slow?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Minime, honest master; or rather, master, no.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I say lead is slow.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: You are too swift, sir, to say so:
Is that lead slow which is fired from a gun?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Sweet smoke of rhetoric!
He reputes me a cannon; and the bullet, that's he:
I shoot thee at the swain.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Thump then and I flee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: A most acute juvenal; volable and free of grace!
By thy favour, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face:
Most rude melancholy, valour gives thee place.
My herald is return'd. Re-enter MOTH with COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l:
A wonder, master! here's a costard broken in a
shin.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l:
Some enigma, some riddle: come, thy l'envoy;
begin.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
No egma, no riddle, no l'envoy; no 
salve in the 
mail, sir:
       O, sir, plantain, a 
plain plantain! no 
l'envoy; no l'envoy;
       no 
salve, sir, but a plantain!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
By virtue, thou enforcest laughter;
thy silly
thought my spleen; the heaving of
my lungs provokes
me to ridiculous smiling.
O, pardon me, my stars! Doth
the inconsiderate
take salve for l'envoy, and the word l'envoy
for a salve?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
Do the wise think them other? is
not l'envoy a
salve?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: No, page: it is an epilogue or discourse, to make plain
Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been sain.
I will example it:
The fox, the ape and the humble-bee,
Were still at odds, being but three.
There's the moral. Now the l'envoy.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: I will add the l'envoy. Say the moral again.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: The fox, the ape, the humble-bee,
Were still at odds, being but three.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Until the goose came out of door,
And stay'd the odds by adding four.
sp.p:
Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow
with
my l'envoy.
sp.l: The fox, the ape and the humble-bee,
Were still at odds, being but three.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Until the goose came out of door,
Staying the odds by adding four.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l:
A good l'envoy, ending in the goose: would you
desire more?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: The boy hath sold him a bargain, a goose, that's flat.
Sir, your pennyworth is good, an your goose be fat.
To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose:
Let me see; a fat l'envoy; ay, that's a fat goose.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l:
Come hither, come hither.
How did this argument begin?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: By saying that a costard was broken in a shin.
Then call'd you for the l'envoy.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l:
True, and I for a plantain:
thus came your argument in;
Then the boy's fat l'envoy, the goose that you bought;
And he ended the market.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
But tell me; how was there a costard
broken in
a shin?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I will tell you sensibly.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Thou hast no feeling of it, Moth:
I
will speak that l'envoy:
sp.l: I Costard, running out, that was safely within,
Fell over the threshold, and broke my shin.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: We will talk no more of this matter.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: Till there be more matter in the shin.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Sirrah Costard, I will enfranchise thee.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
O, marry me to one Frances: I
smell some l'envoy,
some goose, in this.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
By my sweet soul, I mean setting
thee at liberty,
enfreedoming thy person: thou
wert immured,
restrained, captivated, bound.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
True, true; and now you will be my
purgation
and let me loose.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I give thee thy liberty, set thee from
durance;
and, in lieu thereof, impose on thee
nothing but this:
bear this significant[giving a letter]
to the country maid Jaquenetta:
there
is remuneration; for the best ward of mine
honor
is rewarding my dependents. Moth,
follow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l:
Like the sequel, I.
Signior Costard, adieu.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l:
My sweet ounce of man's flesh! my incony
Jew! Exit Moth.
Now will I look to his remuneration.
Remuneration!
O, that's the Latin word for three
farthings:
three farthings--remuneration.--
'What's the price
of this inkle?'--'One
penny.'--'No, I'll give you a remuneration:'
why,
it carries it. Remuneration! why, it is a
fairer name than
French crown. I will never
buy and sell out of this
word.
Enter BIRON.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
O, my good knave Costard! exceedingly
well met.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Pray you, sir, how much carnation
ribbon
may a man buy for a remuneration?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: What is a remuneration?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Why, then, three-farthing worth of silk.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: I thank your worship: God be wi' you!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Stay, slave; I must employ thee:
As thou wilt win my favour, good my knave,
Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: When would you have it done, sir?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: This afternoon.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Well, I will do it, sir: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: Thou knowest not what it is.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: I shall know, sir, when I have done it.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Why, villain, thou must know first.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: I will come to your worship to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p: It must be done this afternoon.
Hark, slave, it is but this:
sp.l: The princess comes to hunt here in the park,
And in her train there is a gentle lady;
When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name,
And Rosaline they call her: ask for her;
And to her white hand see thou do commend
This seal'd-up counsel. There's thy guerdon; go. Giving him a shilling.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Gardon, O sweet gardon! better
than remuneration,
a 'leven-pence farthing better:
most sweet gardon!
I will do it, sir, in
print. Gardon! Remuneration!
Exit.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l:
And I, forsooth, in love!
I, that
have been love's whip;
A very beadle to a humorous sigh;

A critic,
nay, a night-watch constable;
A domineering pedant o'er the boy;
Than whom no mortal so magnificent!
This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy;
This senior-junior, giant-dwarf, Dan Cupid;
Regent of love-rhymes, lord of folded arms,
The anointed sovereign of sighs and groans,
Liege of all loiterers and malcontents,
Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces,
Sole imperator and great general
Of trotting 'paritors:--O my little heart:--
And I to be a corporal of his field,
And wear his colours like a tumbler's hoop!
What, I! I love! I sue! I seek a wife!
A woman, that is like a German clock,
Still a-repairing, ever out of frame,
And never going aright. being a watch,
But being watch'd that it may still go right!
Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all;
And, among three, to love the worst of all;
A wightly wanton with a velvet brow,
With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes;
Ay, and, by heaven, one that will do the deed
Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard:
And I to sigh for her! to watch for her!
To pray for her! Go to; it is a plague
That Cupid will impose for my neglect
Of his almighty dreadful little might.
Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue and groan:
Some men must love my lady and some Joan. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: Enter the Princess, and her train, a Forester, BOYET, ROSALINE, MARIA, and KATHARINE.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Was that the king, that spurr'd his horse so hard
Against the steep uprising of the hill?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: I know not; but I think it was not he.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Whoe'er a' was, a' show'd a mounting mind.
Well, lords, to-day we shall have our dispatch:
On Saturday we will return to France.
Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush
That we must stand and play the murderer in?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice;
A stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot,
And thereupon thou speak'st the fairest shoot.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: What, what? first praise me and again say no?
O short-lived pride! Not fair? alack for woe!

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Yes, madam, fair.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay, never paint me now:
Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow.
Here, good my glass, take this for telling true:
Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: See, see, my beauty will be saved by merit!
O heresy in fair, fit for these days!
A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.
But come, the bow: now mercy goes to kill,
And shooting well is then accounted ill.
Thus will I save my credit in the shoot:
Not wounding, pity would not let me do't:
If wounding, then it was to show my skill,
That more for praise than purpose meant to kill.
And out of question so it is sometimes,
Glory grows guilty of detested crimes,
When, for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part,
We bend to that the working of the heart;
As I for praise alone now seek to spill
The poor deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Do not curst wives hold that selfsovereignty
Only for praise sake, when they strive to be
Lords o'er their lords?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Only for praise: and praise we may afford
To any lady that subdues a lord.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Here comes a member of the commonwealth. Enter COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
God dig-you-den all! Pray you,
which is the head
lady?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the
rest that have
no heads.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Which is the greatest lady, the highest?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: The thickest and the tallest.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: The thickest and the tallest! it is so; truth is truth.
An your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit,
One o' these maids' girdles for your waist should be fit.
Are not you the chief woman? you are the thickest here.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: What's your will, sir? what's your will?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l:
I have a letter from Monsieur Biron
to one Lady Rosaline.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: O, thy letter, thy letter! he's a good friend of mine:

Stand aside, good bearer.
Boyet, you can carve;
Break up this capon.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: I am bound to serve.
This letter is mistook, it importeth none here;
It is writ to Jaquenetta.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: We will read it, I swear.
Break the neck of the wax, and every one give ear.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p:
'By heaven, that thou art
fair, is most infallible; true,
that thou art
beauteous; truth itself, that thou art
lovely.
More fairer than fair, beautiful than beauteous,
truer than truth itself, have commiseration
on thy heroical
vassal! The magnanimous and
most illustrate king
Cophetua set eye upon the
pernicious and indubitate beggar
Zenelophon;
and he it was that might rightly say, Veni,
vidi, vici; which to annothanize in the vulgar,
--O
base and obscure vulgar!--videlicet, He
came, saw, and overcame:
he came, one; saw
two; overcame, three.
Who came? the king:
why did he come? to see: why
did he see?
to overcome: to whom come he? to the
beggar:
what saw he? the baggar: who overcame
he? the beggar. The conclusion is victory:
on whose
side? the king's. The captive
is enriched: on whose side?
the beggar's. The
catastrophe is a nuptial: on whose
side? the
king's: no, on both in one, or one in both.
I am
the king; for so stands the comparison:
thou the beggar;
for so witnesseth thy lowliness.
Shall I command
thy love? I may: shall
I enforce thy love? I could:
shall I entreat
thy love? I will. What shalt thou exchange
for rags? robes; for tittles? titles; for thyself?
me. Thus, expecting thy reply, I profane
my lips on
thy foot, my eyes on thy picture,
and my heart on thy
every part.
Thine, in the
dearest design of industry,
DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.'
sp.l: Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar
'Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey.
Submissive fall his princely feet before,
And he from forage will incline to play:
But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then?
Food for his rage, repasture for his den.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l:
What plume of feathers is he that indited this
letter?

What vane? what weathercock? did you
ever hear better?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Else your memory is bad, going o'er it erewhile.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: This Armado is a Spaniard, that keeps here in court;
A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport
To the prince and his bookmates.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Thou fellow, a word:
Who gave thee this letter?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: I told you; my lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: To whom shouldst thou give it?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: From my lord to my lady.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: From which lord to which lady?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: From my lord Biron, a good master of mine,
To a lady of France that he call'd Rosaline.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away. [To Ros.[

Here, sweet, put up this; 'twill be thine another day.
[Exeunt Princess and train.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Who is the suitor? who is the suitor?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Shall I teach you to know?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Ay, my continent of beauty.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why, she that bears the bow.
Finely put off!

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: My lady goes to kill horns; but, if thou marry,
Hang me by the neck, if horns that year miscarry.
Finely put on!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Well, then, I am the shooter.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: And who is your deer?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near.
Finely put on, indeed!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l:
You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she
strikes at the brow.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l:
But she herself is hit lower:
have I hit her now?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Shall I come upon thee with an old
saying, that
was a man when King Pepin of
France was a little boy, as
touching the hit it?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p:
So I may answer thee with one as
old, that
was a woman when Queen Guinover
of Britain was a
little wench, as touching the
hit it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it,
Thou canst not hit it, my good man.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: An I cannot, cannot, cannot,
An I cannot, another can.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: By my troth, most pleasant: how both did fit it!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l:
A mark marvellous well shot, for they both
did hit it.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l:
A mark! O, mark but that mark! A mark, says
my lady!
Let the mark have a prick in't, to mete at, if it may be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wide o' the bow hand! i' faith, your hand is out.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l:
Indeed, a' must shoot nearer, or he'll ne'er hit
the clout.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l:
An if my hand be out, then belike your hand
is in.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l:
Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the
pin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l:
Come, come, you talk greasily; your lips grow
foul.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l:
She's too hard for you at pricks, sir: challenge her
to bowl.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l:
I fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good
owl. Exeunt Boyet and Maria.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: By my soul, a swain! a most simple clown!
Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down!
O' my troth, most sweet jests! most incony vulgar wit!

When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely, as it were,
so fit.
Armado o' th' one side,--O, a most dainty man!
To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan!

To see him kiss his hand! and how most sweetly a' will
swear!
And his page o' t' other side, that handful of wit!
Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit!

Sola, sola!
[Shout within. [Exit Costard, running.

div.head: SCENE II
div.stage: Enter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, and DULL.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Very reverend sport, truly; and
done in the testimony
of a good conscience.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
The deer was, as you know, sanguis,
in blood;
ripe as the pomewater, who now
hangeth like a jewel in
the ear of caelo, the
sky, the welkin, the heaven; and anon
falleth
like a crab on the face of terra, the soil, the
land, the earth.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Truly, Master Holofernes, the epithets
are
sweetly varied, like a scholar at the
least: but, sir, I assure
ye, it was a buck of
the first head.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.l: 'Twas not a haud credo; 'twas a pricket.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Most barbarous intimation! yet a
kind of insinuation,
as it were, in via, in way,
of explication; facere, as
it were, replication,
or rather, ostentare, to show, as it were,
his inclination,
after his undressed, unpolished, uneducated,
unpruned, untrained, or rather, unlettered,
or ratherest,
unconfirmed fashion, to
insert again my haud credo
for a deer.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.l:
I said the deer was not a haud credo; 'twas a
pricket.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: Twice-sod simplicity, bis coctus!

O thou monster
Ignorance, how deformed dost thou look!

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Sir, he hath never fed of the dainties
that are
bred in a book;
he hath not eat paper,
as it were;
he hath not drunk ink:
his
intellect is not replenished; he is only an animal,
only sensible in the duller parts:
And such barren plants
are set before us, that
we thankful should be,
Which we of
taste and feeling are, for those
parts that do fructify in
us more than he.
For as it would ill become me to be vain, indiscreet,
or
a fool,
So were there a patch set on learning, to see
him in a
school:
But omne bene, say I; being of an old father's mind,
Many can brook the weather that love not the wind.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.l:
You two are book-men: can you tell me by your
wit

What was a month old at Cain's birth, that's not five
weeks old as yet?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l:
Dictynna, goodman Dull; Dictynna, goodman
Dull.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.l: What is Dictynna?

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.l: A title to Phoebe, to Luna, to the moon.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l:
The moon was a month old when Adam was
no more.
And raught not to five weeks when he came to five-score.
The allusion holds in the exchange.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.l:
'Tis true indeed: the collusion holds in the
exchange.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: God comfort thy capacity! I say, the

allusion holds
in the exchange.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
And I say, the pollusion holds in the
exchange;
for the moon is never but a month
old: and I say beside
that, 'twas a pricket that
the princess killed.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal
epitaph on the death of the deer? And,
to humor
the ignorant, call I the deer the princess
killed a
pricket.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Perge, good Master Holofernes,
perge; so it shall
please you to abrogate scurrility.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l:
I will something affect the letter, for it argues
facility.

The preyful princess pierced and prick'd
a pretty pleasing pricket;

Some say a sore; but not a sore,
till now made sore with shooting.

The dogs did yell; put L to sore,
then sorel jumps from thicket;

Or pricket sore, or else sorel;
the people fall a-hooting.

If sore be sore, then L to sore
makes fifty sores one sorel.

Of one sore I an hundred make
by adding but one more L.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p: A rare talent!

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
If a talent be a claw, look
how he claws him
with a talent.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
This is a gift that I have, simple, simple;
a foolish
extravagant spirit, full of forms,
figures, shapes, objects,
ideas, apprehensions,
motions, revolutions: these
are begot in the
ventricle of memory, nourished in the
womb
of pia mater, and delivered upon the mellowing
of occasion. But the gift is good in those in
whom it is
acute, and I am thankful for it.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Sir, I praise the Lord for you: and
so may my
parishioners; for their sons are
well tutored by you,
and their daughters profit
very greatly under you: you
are a good member
of the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Mehercle, if their sons be ingenuous,
they
shall want no instruction; if their daughters
be capable,
I will put it to them: but vir
sapit qui pauca loquitur; a
soul feminine saluteth
us. Enter JAQUENETTA and COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: God give you good morrow, master Parson.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Master Parson, quasi pers-on. An if
one should
be pierced, which is the one?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
Marry, master schoolmaster, he that
is likest to a
hogshead.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Piercing a hogshead! a good lustre of
conceit
in a tuft of earth; fire enough for a
flint, pearl
enough for a swine: 'tis pretty; it
is well.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p:
Good master Parson, be so good as
read me
this letter: it was given me by Costard,
and sent me
from Don Armado: I beseech
you, read it.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Fauste, precor gelida quando pecus
omne sub umbra Ruminat,
--and so forth. Ah,
good old Mantuan! I
may speak of thee as
the traveller doth of Venice;
sp.l:
Venetia,
Venetia,
Chi non ti vede non ti pretia.
sp.p:
Old Mantuan,
old Mantuan! who understandeth
thee not, loves thee not. Ut, re,
sol, la, mi,
fa. Under pardon, sir, what are the contents?
or
rather, as Horace says in his--What, my
soul, verses?

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p: Ay, sir, and very learned.

sp.speaker: Hol.
Nath.
sp.l: If love make me forsworn, how shall I swear to love?
Ah, never faith could hold, if not to beauty vow'd!
Though to myself forsworn, to thee I'll faithful prove;

Those thoughts to me were oaks, to thee like osiers
bow'd.
Study his bias leaves and makes his book thine eyes,

Where all those pleasures live that art would
comprehend:
If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice;
Well learned is that tongue that well can thee commend,
All ignorant that soul that sees thee without wonder;
Which is to me some praise that I thy parts admire:

Thy eye Jove's lightning bears, thy voice his dreadful
thunder,
Which, not to anger bent, is music and sweet fire.
Celestial as thou art, O, pardon, love, this wrong,
That sings heaven's praise with such an earthly tongue.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
You find not the apostraphas, and so
miss the
accent: let me supervise the canzonet.
Here are only numbers ratified; but, for
the
elegancy, facility, and golden cadence of
poesy, caret. Ovidius
Naso was the man: and
why, indeed, Naso, but
for smelling out the
odoriferous flowers of fancy, the
jerks of invention?
Imitari is nothing: so doth the
hound
his master, the ape his keeper, the tired horse
his rider. But, damosella virgin, was this directed
to
you?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p:
Ay, sir, from one Monsieur Biron,
one of the
strange queen's lords.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
I will overglance the superscript:
'To
the snow-white hand of the most beauteous
Lady Rosaline.'
I will look again on the intellect
of the letter, for
the nomination of the
party writing to the person written
unto:
'Your ladyship's in all desired employment,
BIRON.'
Sir Nathaniel, this Biron is one ofthe
votaries
with the king; and here he hath
framed a letter to a sequent
of the stranger
queen's, which accidentally, or
by the way of
progression, hath miscarried. Trip and
go, my
sweet; deliver this paper into the royal hand
of the
king: it may concern much. Stay not
thy compliment; I
forgive thy duty: adieu.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l:
Good Costard, go with me.
Sir, God save your life!

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Have with thee, my girl. Exeunt Cost. and Jaq.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Sir, you have done this in the fear of
God, very
religiously; and, as a certain father
saith,--

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Sir, tell not me of the father; I do
fear colorable
colors. But to return to the
verses: did they please
you, Sir Nathaniel?

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p: Marvellous well for the pen.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
I do dine to-day at the father's of a
certain pupil
of mine; where, if, before repast,
it shall please you to
gratify the table with a
grace, I will, on my privilege I
have with the
parents of the foresaid child or pupil,
undertake
your ben venuto; where I will prove those
verses to be very unlearned, neither savouring
of
poetry, wit, nor invention: I beseech your
society.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
And thank you too; for society, saith
the text,
is the happiness of life.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
And, certes, the text most infallibly
concludes it.To Dull
Sir, I do invite you
too; you shall not say me nay: pauca
verba.
Away! the gentles are at their game, and we
will to our
recreation. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
The king he is hunting the deer;
I
am coursing myself:
they have pitched a toil;
I am toiling in a pitch,
--pitch that defiles:
defile! a foul word. Well, set thee
down, sorrow!
for so they say the fool said, and so say
I, and I the fool: well proved, wit! By the
Lord, this
love is as mad as Ajax: it kills
sheep; it kills me, I a
sheep: well proved
again o' my side! I will not love:
if I do, hang
me; i' faith, I will not. O, but her eye,--by
this light, but for her eye, I would not love
her; yes, for
her two eyes. Well, I do nothing
in the world but lie,
and lie in my throat. By
heaven, I do love: and it hath
taught me to
rhyme and to be melancholy; and here is
part
of my rhyme, and here my melancholy. Well,
she
hath one o' my sonnets already: the clown
bore it, the
fool sent it, and the lady hath it:
sweet clown, sweeter
fool, sweetest lady! By
the world, I would not care
a pin, if the other
three were in. Here comes one with a
paper:
God give him grace to groan!
Stands aside. Enter the King, with a paper.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ay, me!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
Shot, by heaven! Proceed,
sweet Cupid: thou hast
thumped him with thy
bird-bolt under the left pap. In faith,
secrets!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So sweet a kiss the golden sun gives not
To those fresh morning drops upon the rose,
As thy eye-beams, when their fresh rays have smote
The night of dew that on my cheeks down flows:
Nor shines the silver moon one half so bright
Through the transparent bosom of the deep,
As doth thy face through tears of mine give light;
Thou shinest in every tear that I do weep:
No drop but as a coach doth carry thee;
So ridest thou triumphing in my woe,
Do but behold the tears that swell in me,
And they thy glory through my grief will show:
But do not love thyself; then thou wilt keep
My tears for glasses, and still make me weep.
O queen of queens! how far dost thou excel,
No thought can think, nor tongue of mortal tell.
How shall she know my griefs? I'll drop the paper:

Sweet leaves, shade folly. Who is he comes here?
Steps aside
What, Longaville! and reading! listen, ear.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Now, in thy likeness, one more fool appear! Enter LONGAVILLE, with a paper.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Ay me, I am forsworn!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.p:
Why, he comes in like a perjure,
wearing papers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: In love, I hope: sweet fellowship in shame!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: One drunkard loves another of the name.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Am I the first that have been perjured so?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: I could put thee in comfort. Not by two that I know:
Thou makest the triumviry, the corner-cap of society,
The shape of Love's Tyburn that hangs up simplicity.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I fear these stubborn lines lack power to move.
O sweet Maria, empress of my love!
These numbers will I tear, and write in prose.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: O, rhymes are guards on wanton Cupid's hose:
Disfigure not his slop.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This same shall go. Reads.
Did not the heavenly rhetoric of thine eye,
'Gainst whom the world cannot hold argument,
Persuade my heart to this false perjury?
Vows for thee broke deserve not punishment.
A woman I forswore; but I will prove,
Thou being a goddess, I forswore not thee:
My vow was earthly, thou a heavenly love;
Thy grace being gain'd cures all disgrace in me.
Vows are but breath, and breath a vapour is:
Then thou, fair sun, which on my earth dost shine,
Exhalest this vapour-vow; in thee it is:
If broken then, it is no fault of mine:
If by me broke, what fool is not so wise
To lose an oath to win a paradise?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: This is the liver-vein, which makes flesh a deity,
A green goose a goddess: pure, pure idolatry.
God amend us, God amend! we are much out o' the way.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: By whom shall I send this?--Company! stay. Steps aside.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: All hid, all hid; an old infant play.
Like a demigod here sit I in the sky,
And wretched fools' secrets heedfully o'er-eye.
More sacks to the mill! O heavens, I have my wish! Enter DUMAIN, with a paper.
Dumain transform'd! four woodcocks in a dish!

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: O most divine Kate!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: O most profane coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: By heaven, the wonder in a mortal eye!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: By earth, she is not, corporal, there you lie.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Her amber hair for foul hath amber quoted.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: An amber-colour'd raven was well noted.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: As upright as the cedar.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Stoop, I say;
Her shoulder is with child.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: As fair as day.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Ay, as some days; but then no sun must shine.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: O that I had my wish!

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And I had mine!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And I mine too, good Lord!

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Amen, so I had mine: is not that a good word?

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: I would forget her; but a fever she
Reigns in my blood and will remember'd be.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: A fever in your blood! why, then incision
Would let her out in saucers: sweet misprision!

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Once more I'll read the ode that I have writ.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Once more I'll mark how love can vary wit.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: On a day--alack the day!--
Love, whose month is ever May,
Spied a blossom passing fair
Playing in the wanton air:
Through the velvet leaves the wind,
All unseen, can passage find;
That the lover, sick to death,
Wish himself the heaven's breath.
Air, quoth he, thy cheeks may blow;
Air, would I might triumph so!
But, alack, my hand is sworn
Ne'er to pluck thee from thy thorn;
Vow, alack, for youth unmeet,
Youth so apt to pluck a sweet!
Do not call it sin in me,
That I am forsworn for thee;
Thou for whom Jove would swear
Juno but an Ethiope were;
And deny himself for Jove,
Turning mortal for thy love.
This will I send and something else more plain,
That shall express my true love's fasting pain.
O, would the king, Biron, and Longaville,
Were lovers too! Ill, to example ill,
Would from my forehead wipe a perjured note;
For none offend where all alike do dote.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Dumain, thy love is far from charity,
That in love's grief desirest society:
You may look pale, but I should blush, I know,
To be o'erheard and taken napping so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come, sir, you blush; as his your case is such;
You chide at him, offending twice as much;
You do not love Maria; Longaville
Did never sonnet for her sake compile,
Nor never lay his wreathed arms athwart
His loving bosom to keep down his heart.
I have been closely shrouded in this bush
And mark'd you both and for you both did blush:
I heard your guilty rhymes, observed your fashion,
Saw sighs reek from you, noted well your passion:
Ay me! says one; Jove! the other cries;
One, her hairs were gold, crystal the other's eyes: To Long.
You would for paradise break faith and troth; To Dum.
And Jove, for your love, would infringe an oath.
What will Biron say when that he shall hear
Faith so infringed, which such zeal did swear?
How will he scorn! how will he spend his wit!
How will he triumph, leap and laugh at it!
For all the wealth that ever I did see,
I would not have him know so much by me.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Now step I forth to whip hypocrisy. Advancing.
Ah, good my liege, I pray thee, pardon me!
Good heart, what grace hast thou, thus to reprove
These worms for loving, that art most in love?
Your eyes do make no coaches; in your tears
There is no certain princess that appears;
You'll not be perjured, 'tis a hateful thing;
Tush, none but minstrels like of sonneting!
But are you not ashamed? nay, are you not,
All three of you, to be thus much o'ershot?
You found his mote; the king your mote did see;
But I a beam do find in each of three.
O, what a scene of foolery have I seen,
Of sighs, of groans, of sorrow and of teen!
O me, with what strict patience have I sat,
To see a king transformed to a gnat!
To see great Hercules whipping a gig,
And profound Solomon to tune a jig,
And Nestor play at push-pin with the boys,
And critic Timon laugh at idle toys!
Where lies thy grief, O, tell me, good Dumain?
And, gentle Longaville, where lies thy pain?
And where my liege's? all about the breast:
A caudle, ho!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Too bitter is thy jest.
Are we betray'd thus to thy over-view?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Not you to me, but I betray'd by you:
I, that am honest; I, that hold it sin
To break the vow I am engaged in;
I am betray'd, by keeping company
With men like men of inconstancy.
When shall you see me write a thing in rhyme?
Or groan for love? or spend a minute's time
In pruning me? When shall you hear that I

Will praise a
hand, a foot, a face, an eye,

A gait, a state, a brow, a breast,
a waist,
A leg, a limb?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Soft! whither away so fast
A true man or a thief that gallops so?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l:
I post from love: good lover, let me go.
Enter JAQUENETTA and COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: God bless the king!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What present hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: Some certain treason.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What makes treason here?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: Nay, it makes nothing, sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If it mar nothing neither,
The treason and you go in peace away together.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I beseech your grace, let this letter be read:
Our parson misdoubts it; 'twas treason, he said.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Biron, read it over. Giving him the paper.
Where hadst thou it?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Of Costard.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where hadst thou it ?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: Of Dun Adramadio, Dun Adramadio. Biron tears the letter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now! what is in you? why dost thou tear it?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l:
A toy, my liege, a toy: your grace needs not
fear it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l:
It did move him to passion, and therefore let's
hear it.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: It is Biron's writing, and here is his name. Gathering up the pieces.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l:
Ah, you whoreson loggerhead! you were born
to do me shame.
Guilty, my lord, guilty! I confess, I confess.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l:
That you three fools lack'd me fool to make
up the mess:
He, he, and you, and you, my liege, and I,
Are pick-purses in love, and we deserve to die.
O, dismiss this audience, and I shall tell you more.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Now the number is even.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: True, true; we are four.

Will these turtles
be gone?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hence, sirs; away!

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.l: Walk aside the true folk, and let the traitors stay. Exeunt Costard and Jaquenetta.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Sweet lords, sweet lovers, O, let us embrace!
As true we are as flesh and blood can be:
The sea will ebb and flow, heaven show his face;
Young blood doth not obey an old decree:
We cannot cross the cause why we were born;
Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l:
What, did these rent lines show some love of
thine?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Did they, quoth you? Who sees the heavenly Rosaline,
That, like a rude and savage man of Inde,
At the first opening of the gorgeous east,
Bows not his vassal head and strucken blind
Kisses the base ground with obedient breast?
What peremptory eagle-sighted eye
Dares look upon the heaven of her brow,
That is not blinded by her majesty?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What zeal, what fury hath inspired thee now?
My love, her mistress, is a gracious moon;
She an attending star, scarce seen a light.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Biron:
O, but for my love, day would turn to night!
Of all complexions the cull'd sovereignty
Do meet, as at a fair, in her fair cheek,
Where several worthies make one dignity,
Where nothing wants that want itself doth seek.
Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues,--
Fie, painted rhetoric! O, she needs it not:
To things of sale a seller's praise belongs,
She passes praise; then praise too short doth blot.
A wither'd hermit, five-score winters worn,
Might shake off fifty, looking in her eye:
Beauty doth varnish age, as if new-born,
And gives the crutch the cradle's infancy:
O, 'tis the sun that maketh all things shine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By heaven, thy love is black as ebony.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Is ebony like her? O wood divine!
A wife of such wood were felicity.
O, who can give an oath? where is a book?
That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack,
If that she learn not of her eye to look:
No face is fair that is not full so black.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O paradox ! Black is the badge of hell,
The hue of dungeons and the suit of night;
And beauty's crest becomes the heavens well.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Devils soonest tempt, resembling spirits of light.
O, if in black my lady's brows be deck'd,
It mourns that painting and usurping hair
Should ravish doters with a false aspect;
And therefore is she born to make black fair.
Her favour turns the fashion of the days,
For native blood is counted painting now;
And therefore red, that would avoid dispraise,
Paints itself black, to imitate her brow.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: To look like her are chimney-sweepers black.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And since her time are colliers counted bright.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And Ethiopes of their sweet complexion crack.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Dark needs no candles now, for dark is light.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Your mistresses dare never come in rain,
For fear their colours should be wash'd away.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Twere good, yours did; for, sir, to tell you plain,
I'll find a fairer face not wash'd to-day.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: I'll prove her fair, or talk till doomsday here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No devil will fright thee then so much as she.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Look, here's thy love: my foot and her face see.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: O, if the streets were paved with thine eyes,
Her feet were much too dainty for such tread!

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: O vile! then, as she goes, what upward lies
The street should see as she walk'd overhead.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But what of this? are we not all in love?

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: Nothing so sure; and thereby all forsworn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then leave this chat; and, good Biron, now prove
Our loving lawful, and our faith not torn.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Ay, marry, there; some flattery for this evil.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O, some authority how to proceed;
Some tricks, some quillets, how to cheat the devil.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Some salve for perjury.

sp.speaker: Biron.
sp.l: 'Tis more than need.
Have at you, then, affection's men at arms.
Consider what you first did swear unto,
To fast, to study, and to see no woman;
Flat treason 'gainst the kingly state of youth.
